Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: US Ignite: High School STEM Education Utilizing Gigabit HD Multipoint Connected Collaboration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will demonstrate and assesses the value of low-latency, high-quality video and audio in an educational setting. Traditional teleconferencing has not worked well in schools due to the unnatural communication style forced by latency and difficulty in setting up the equipment. The project will develop a system that substitutes SDN technology, network bandwidth, and end-host manipulation of video and audio, as a replacement for a Multipoint Control Unit (MCU) for bridging multiple users into a collaborative system. Combined with minimal encoding of the audio and video data these features allow for very low latency and a much more natural interaction style. The technology will be used and assessed in educational environments. The project plans include the lesson and evaluation plans that will enable the assessment of the utility of low-latency, high-quality, easy-to-use technology.

This project will contribute to our understanding of the value of advanced networking in support of high-quality, low-latency media to connect students to skilled teachers and to other students. It will test the hypothesis that connected collaboration provides an environment in which students can initiate collaboration sessions with their peers, teachers and subject matter experts enabling them to engage in challenging, authentic, real world, and just in time problem solving. The student's "Connected Learning" is achieved through the myriad of interaction configurations that the multi-point technology facilitates, allowing students and teachers in the same classroom, in different classrooms or even different schools to interact with each other and collaborate with outside experts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported creating Connected Collaboration, a multipoint videoconferencing system for gigabit networks. Even with 3 or more endpoints, the system does not use an MCU or conferencing bridge, It is a highly modified derivative of the GStreamer open source multimedia library (https://gstreamer.freedesktop.org/). Connected Collaboration currently offers linux and Mac OS X clients. It requires gigabit networks between the endpoints. The software may be downloaded from the its temporary github repository with the following command:
git clone https://github.com/jhgorse/ConnectedCollaboration.git.

It was used in high school STEM education to connect classes to experts in their offices or labs so that the students could learn about the most exciting developments in various STEM disciplines. The project supported a qualitative analysis of the effectiveness of the software. The following is a direct quote from the qualitative analysis.

"As we strive to meet the needs of students and to prepare them for the global job market of the 21st century, teleconnected learning opportunities such as the one that this grant supported are paramount. These new technologies allow students to communicate and learn alongside experts they otherwise would not have access to. The collaboration allows students to deepen their understanding of the global community by exposing them to a myriad of perspectives on current social and scientific issues such as sustainability and food growth and availability."

That was the goal of the project.
